thread.title: Sonora woman trial set in co-worker stabbing
thread.title_full: Sonora woman trial set in co-worker stabbing

title: Sonora woman trial set in co-worker stabbing
text: Sonora woman trial set in co-worker stabbing Sonora woman trial set in co-worker stabbing By Tori Thomas, The Union Democrat October 17, 2015 09:48 am A Nov. 18 trial date has been set for a Sonora woman accused of stabbing her coworker in May. Judge James. A. Boscoe set the date Friday in Tuolumne County Superior Court. Meghan Myra Hardin, 21, of Sonora, was arrested May 6 and charged with felony assault with a deadly weapon. According to the Tuolumne County Sheriff’s Office, deputies responded to a report of a stabbing about 1 a.m. May 6 at a gas station on Mono Way near Standard Road. When deputies arrived, they found a 22-year-old woman with a stab wound to her leg. The woman, an employee at Rosalinda’s Gentlemen's Club west of Jamestown, said she and her co-worker got into an argument that turned physical. Hardin pleaded not guilty May 22 before Tuolumne County Superior Court Judge Eleanor Provost. A trial readiness conference is scheduled for Nov. 9. Follow UnionDemocrat.com
